content.description:
NOTE: Route currently under construction but bound to be another classic!

 This line will start in the lower dihedral formation, just right of Bee Hive.
content.location: Start in the obvious dihedral feature just right of Bee Hive. Follow the steep slab to the steeper face above.

content.description:
NOTE: Route currently under construction but bound to be another classic!

 This line will start on the far left side of the cave, following a steep face to a ledge above the cave, then continuing up the face above.
content.location: On the far left side of the cave, start by following the steep face to a ledge above the cave.

content.description:
NOTE: Route currently under construction but bound to be another classic!

 This will be another perma-draw sport route just left of the center of the cave.
content.location: Start on the left side of the cave roof and follow a line of pockets and bolts.

content.description: This slightly overhanging route, located at the bottom of the steps, is just on the right side of the cave and extended another 15 ft, in May of 2018, to continue through the upper roof bulge. Permadraws protect the crux and last few bolts so go ahead and warm up on this line. An easy clip rap anchor allows for a quick, clean finish. I recommend this line for those of you wanting to warm-up for the harder lines at Robinson. Bouldering: Feel free to sit start, using the pockets. Crux: tends to be the mid section of the climb, at the third bolt. Be happy with the slopers then a fist jam helps you get past the large, horizontal pocket.
content.location: This is the first route you come to, just south of the bottom of the stairs.

content.description: Bolted by Jim Thurmond, during the first year or so of Robinson’s development, as a great test piece for the stronger climbers visiting the area. The start of the route continues to grow longer, as a bouldering problem with a sit start in the cave. Enjoy the boulder problem or give it a go as a standing start from below the first bolt perma-draw.
content.location: Just to the left of Pillow Fort at the bottom of the stairs.

content.description: Last Climb: This is the first approach descent and the last climb of the day. Be sure to log your ascent of this classic last climb of the day! Repeat as needed! Thanks Bill for having the stairs built for all of us to enjoy.
content.protection: Hand railing provided along with rest areas.

content.description: Nice long moderate climb. Mostly less than vertical, with a few steeper sections mixed in for some fun. At points you can choose left or right for a short section and depending which way you go it will vary the difficulty.
content.protection: 15 bolts plus anchors with chains and mussy hooks.
content.location: Right route on the obvious tall wall climber's left of the staircase and cave.

content.description: 70M rope recommended. Feel free to climb this line as a single pitch if you're using a 70M rope or a double rope system.P1: The first pitch of this tall line starts on a section of light colored rock, below the first tan colored bolt, then follows a slab of vertical edged formations, just left of Bee Hive. Follow the slab to the first small ledge and alcove, at the next section of light colored rock. A short climb up the right side of this feature gets you to the first rap anchors. 5.6, 50ftP2: The second pitch starts from the belay anchors and heads strait up the vertical face. Passing pockets and vertical edged features, the crux is behind you when you arrive at the upper dihedral. A bolted rap anchor requires a 70M rope or a 50M easily gets you back to the top of the first pitch. 9+, 65ftNote: Climbers, belayers and observers should wear a helmet at all times. Thank you for climbing safely and helping keep the routes clean of loose rocks.
content.location: Start below the small lower roof, left of Bee Hive, and follow the slab to gain the first set of anchors.

content.description: 70M rope recommended. 60 meter rope optional if you rap from the first set of rap anchors, 15 feet below the lip of the cliff. A slightly overhanging start, on the lower face, leads to a nice big ledge. An easier, secondary start follows slab, left of the first few bolts, to the ledge above. A crux overhanging V0 (10b) boulder problem gets you off the ledge, by keeping you slightly right of the bolt. Use of a left heel hook, two intermediate slopers follows by jugs that are level with the next clip. An optional second beta breaker V0- (5.8+) bypass keeps you slightly left of the bolts, requiring a high reach to gain a sloper and jugs left of the next clip. From there, fairly sustained climbing alternates from vertical to slightly less-than-vertical, and finishes with a nice exposed step up to the anchors. The second set of anchors, at the top of the line, is slightly out of sight but up and left.
content.protection: 17 bolts, bolted anchors with chains, hooks, and a quicklink.
content.location:
The left route on the obvious tall wall to climber's left of the staircase and the cave. 

  A 70 meter rope or two ropes are required for descent.

content.description:
Practice rap anchors are provided at the base of this wall!Lilly Wall: This distinctly beautiful, vertical white face has some of the tallest at Robinson. The Lilly Wall is also known as the Beehive Wall because the Beehive route was one of the first lines bolted on the face and remains popular due to it's 5.9 rating. The wall section starts, at the base of the main approach stairs, with a cave entrance and a few overhanging routes. At the base of the main wall, three main routes provide a range of features. Beehive starts on the lower right slab and then offers large pockets on the upper, slightly less then vertical face. 

Routes

range from 45 ft to 120 ft tall and provide a range of moderates to more difficult levels (range from 5.9 to 5.11). A Multi-pitch option offers a 120 ft two pitch climb up the center of the wall (see B Garden). A couple different link up of routes on the main cave overhang, provides a few more challenge options. Start standing or choose a sit start to make the roue harder! Perma-draws are also provided through the crux sections of several of the routes on this wall. Enjoy your workout!

Ratings:

While easier climbs are given a rating number representing the climb to be no harder than the rating represented, routes rated 5.10 and up are given a specific max crux rating. This should help you plan your visit and navigate your way along the bluff while using Mountain Project.

Please provide feedback

using your MP App. Star rating and rate difficulty feedback helps the next visitors use the app.
